title: WCAS RELIGION 482-0-20 Themes in Comparative Religion

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class examines contemporary methods and theory in the study of religion. Readings examine transdisciplinary approaches; theories of race, sexuality, religion, and secularism; and theoretical studies of the method challenges posed by materiality, ethnicity, the state, and the locus of religion. Students write one book review and compose a final research essay.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Although some background in the study of religion is desirable, the seminar is open to all graduate students across disciplines.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will
? learn key interventions made by contemporary authors in the study of religion
? understand the linkage between contemporary method challenges and historical problems in the discipline
? account for the role of social systems in shaping intellectual practices in religious studies
? develop specific approaches to the student's original research informed by critical methods under study

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Assigned readings will include the following:

Bender, Courtney and Pamela Klassen. After Pluralism: Reimagining Religious Engagement.
Chidester, David. Empire of Religion.
Olupona. Jacob. City of 201 Gods.
Orsi, Robert. Between Heaven and Earth.
Matory, J. Lorand. Black Atlantic Religion.
Modern, John. Secularism in Antebellum America.
Taussig, Michael. Magic of the State.
Tweed, Thomas. Crossing and Dwelling.
Vásquez, Manuel. More than Belief.
